title: Clean up extra attributes set in `clipboard_button` helper
description:
## Context

The following discussion from !53224 should be addressed:

- [ ] @pslaughter started a [discussion](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/53224#note_521349698): 

    > **note (non-blocking):** It seems to me that there's a lot of extraneous things we leave in this object we're passing to `data` (i.e. `class` and `hide_tooltip`). When we read these values, I think we intend to pop them out of the object so they don't end up written to the HTML as data attributes (i.e. `data-class`) :thinking: 
    > 
    > This is a pre-existing problem, so it shouldn't block this MR but might be nice to clean up in a follow-up.

On `.com`, you'll notice clipboard buttons have weird data attributes because of this:

![Screen_Shot_2021-03-08_at_2.38.04_PM](/uploads/f25478695291635dfd8a75773dd35793/Screen_Shot_2021-03-08_at_2.38.04_PM.png)

## Investigation Notes

In the [`clipboard_button` helper](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/8fb5f42b7f683815c8929cf4a1f05238132156a2/app/helpers/button_helper.rb#L22), we could probably just use `.delete` instead of reading the various keys so that the keys are also removed and not added to the element's `data` attributes.

title: Releases API update release put fails with `request_contains_malformed_string`
description:
### Summary

I have a job that needs to update a release description, and the description is in markdown. 
The description string is a multi-line string.  

When I run a curl put call to release API endpoint I get nothing back. When I search rail logs I see below error

`curl` returns null and exitcode is `0` 

I would expect an error message

I understand the `multi-line` string is the issue and I will use a better format.  yet I still would like an error message so I am not left trying to figure out what went wrong. We have splunk which helps a ton, would be tough for Dev who does not have access to gitlab logs.  


### error msg

```ruby
Started PUT "/api/v4/projects/11312/releases/1.0.554440" for [IP] at 2021-03-08 13:17:55 -0500
  
ActionDispatch::Http::Parameters::ParseError (783: unexpected token at '{"description": "# v1.0.554372

## Release Verification

### Dependency Check"}'):
  
lib/gitlab/middleware/handle_malformed_strings.rb:37:in `request_contains_malformed_string?'
lib/gitlab/middleware/handle_malformed_strings.rb:19:in `call'
lib/gitlab/middleware/basic_health_check.rb:25:in `call'
lib/gitlab/middleware/handle_ip_spoof_attack_error.rb:25:in `call'
lib/gitlab/middleware/request_context.rb:23:in `call'
config/initializers/fix_local_cache_middleware.rb:9:in `call'
lib/gitlab/metrics/requests_rack_middleware.rb:76:in `call'
lib/gitlab/middleware/release_env.rb:12:in `call'
```

### script

Below is the job I am running 

```yaml
image: registry.gitlab.com/gitlab-org/release-cli:latest
before_script:
    - apk add --update coreutils jq curl
variables:
    REL_NAME: v1.0.$CI_PIPELINE_ID
    REL_TAG: v1.0.$CI_PIPELINE_ID
    #GITLAB_PRIVATE_TOKEN in CICD vars

    
script:
    - | 
      export DESCRIPTION="# ${REL_NAME} - ${REL_TAG}
    
      ## Release verification 
      
      ### Dependency Check"
    
    - | 
      export DATA="{\"description\": \"${DESCRIPTION}\"}"
      echo "Descr => ${DATA}"

    - |
      export URL="${CI_API_V4_URL}/projects/${CI_PROJECT_ID}/releases/${REL_TAG}"
      echo "putting to ${URL}"
      curl --request PUT \
      --header 'Content-Type: application/json' \
      --header "PRIVATE-TOKEN: ${GITLAB_PRIVATE_TOKEN}" \
      --data "${DATA}" \
      ${URL}
```

## Proposal

Return error message: "The parameter is not formatted in JSON"

@JenMcCarthy  
@cherryhan

title: Update requirement models to use requirement issue type
description:
## Overview

This issue is a result of our [Spike - Linking Requirements to Test Cases](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/297270) effort.

## Description

When requirements are migrated to issues (https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/323779, during the migration phase we should make sure that requirement is synced up with its issue), we can update 
related models and services to use the new issue type instead only instead of Requirement model.

But for backwards compatibility we still keep the existing requirement graphql API (used also by UI), so Requirement model could remain just a "proxy" to the requirement issue type.

On Requirement model we could keep only requirement's iid and reference to issue_id (created when migrating requirements to issue type - https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/323779#note_531766143), then model/services used by requirements graphql API would use this `issue_id` to actually to find and update the referenced issue.


## Proposal

- Delegate all attributes in the model [`RequirementsManagement::Requirement`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/ee/app/models/requirements_management/requirement.rb) to the associated `requirement_issue`.
- We should be able to create new requirement records after delegation
- The `state` attribute should be mapped to match the state on the Issue model
- The sync functionality when creating and updating requirements should work after delegation
- The `test_report` association will remain linked to the requirement model because [they need to be migrated to work items](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/7148) before the relationship can be deprecated, so that part of the work will be continued in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/345842.

epic.title: Work Items - Migrate Requirements to Work Items

title: Migrate requirements to issues table
description:
## Overview

This issue is a result of our [Spike - Linking Requirements to Test Cases](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/297270) effort.

## Purpose

We need to migrate requirements into the issue table. In addition, we need to ensure we update references in the requirements_management_test_reports.

* this might be tricky if we want to avoid outage/limited availability of requirements during migration
* Requirement attributes is a subset of Issue attributes. `state` will be changed to `closed` instead of `archived` though
* this conversion will probably break links to existing requirements (e.g. if a requirement URL was `https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/requirements_management/requirements/112`, it would become `https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/987`) - this is related to how much separated we want to have both.

UPDATE: to avoid breaking changes, we could create an issue for each requirement and make sure that both are synced (so when issue is changed, also requirement is changed and vice versa). Then in a next step (https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/323781) we can deprecate requirement model but still keep it as a proxy to the issue.

So in the end requirements API should remain as is (for the deprecation period - https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/329432) acting just as a "proxy" for accessing underlying issues throuhg requirements API.

## Completion

### :white_check_mark: Stage I: relationships

- `requirement_issue_id` to `TestReport`: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/63512
- `test_reports` relationship on `ActsLikeRequirement`: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/63965
- `issue_id` on `Requirement`: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/64189

### :tools: Stage IIa: prohibit unsupported features for Requirement Issues https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/337189
- prohibit moving/cloning of Requirement issues https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/70439
- prohibit other unsupported Issue actions on Requirement Issues (Needs to check if additional actions should be blocked)

### :tools: Stage IIb: logic to sync Requirements with RequirementIssues https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/337190

- Sync deletion https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/64291
- Sync updates
  - title/description https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/64929
  - state - closed/archived and open https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/70607
- Sync creation https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/71104

### :hourglass: Stage III: background migration to migrate unsynced Requirements to RequirementIssues https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/342496

- Merge once Sync Creation is merged
- Migrate all Requirements without issues to a new (synced) Issue of type Requirement https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/71778
- Migrate all requirements test reports to belong to new associated issue https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/345533

### :hourglass: Stage IV: Requirement object becomes a proxy (#323781)

- behind Feature Flag (merge with FF off before Sync Creation merged and data migration merged).
- Switch FF on when data migration finished.

### :hourglass: Stage V: dropping of Requirements table, cleanup #329432

title: Add model restrictions for Requirement issue type
description:
## Overview

This issue is a result of our [Spike - Linking Requirements to Test Cases](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/297270) effort.

## Purpose

It is necessary to define certain model restrictions depending on the associations desired for requirements. For instance, we probably want to restrict the following behaviors for the requirements issue type:

- Adding to Epics
- Adding an Assignee
- Time Tracking

Technical details:
* requirements specific logic could be placed in a module (included in the Issue model), eventually the plan is to make this widgetized - see https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/271171#note_521989053
* for restricting what features are available, we could re-use the same approach implemented for test cases - see Felipe's comment https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/297270#note_508104283
